spans.content: Phosphorus and nitrogen recovery from wastewater by ceramsite: Adsorption mechanism, plant cultivation and sustainability analysis
Qing Shao a, Ying Zhang a, Zhe Liu b, Lizhi Long c, Zizheng Liu a, Yiqun Chen a, Xin-Ming Hu d, Mingming Lu e, Li-Zhi Huang a,f,*
School of Civil Engineering, Wuhan University, No. 8 East Lake South Road, Wuhan 430072, China
b Institute for Population and Development Studies, School of Public Policy and Administration, Xi'an Jiaotong University, Shaanxi Province 710049, China
Key Laboratory of Tea Plant Biology and Resources Utilization (Ministry of Agriculture), Tea Research Institute, Chinese Academy of Agricultural Sciences, Hangzhou 310008, China
Environment Research Institute, Shandong University, Binhai Road 72, Qingdao 266237, China
Department of Chemical and Environmental Engineering, University of Cincinnati, Cincinnati, OH 45221, United States
State Key Laboratory of Water Resources and Hydropower Engineering Science, Wuhan University, 430072, China
- Sewage sludge and fly ash are used to fabricate ceramsite.
- Modified ceramsite effectively recovers N and P from real wastewater effluent.
N&P-adsorbed ceramsite is applied as a fertilizer to promote plant growth.
- Emergy analysis shows high sustainability of the technologies demonstrated.

Recovery of the nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) in wastewater would help to minimize eutrophication and their reuse would lead to a more sustainable society. Sewage sludge and fly ash were used to fabricate ceramsite in the laboratory. After modified with alkali or lanthanum it was shown in benchtop experiments to effectively recover N and P from real wastewater treatment plant effluent. The N&P-adsorbed ceramsite was then applied as an eco-friendly, slow-release fertilizer to promote the germination, growth and blooming of Impatiens commelinoides, realizing the recycling of N and P from wastewater. Emergy analysis shows that such recycling is more sustainable than the current two approaches (i.e., landfill and incineration) for sludge disposal. This work thus demonstrates a sustainable solution combining the reuse of solid waste, effective wastewater purification and recovery of N and P nutrients. Applying the technologies demonstrated would help to minimize the environmental impact of wastewater and solid waste.
Â© 2021 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Recycling valuable nutrients that currently end up in waste is important for a sustainable society. Nitrogen (N) and phosphorus (P) are
* Corresponding author at: School of Civil Engineering, Wuhan University, No. 8 East Lake South Road, Wuhan 430072, China. E-mail address: lizhihuang@whu.edu.cn (L.-Z. Huang).
nutrients essential for living organisms. Ammonia-nitrogen
fertilizer is produced through the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process
and pressures (150-250 bar). The Haber-Bosch process consumes a remarkable fraction of the world's natural gas usage

with copious greenhouse gas emissions (Kitano et al., 2012). The supply of phosphorus, a non-renewable resource, faces a serious risk of depletion within the next 45-100 years. At the same time, excess N and P nutrients released into environment lead to eutrophication and algal blooms. Millions of water bodies are affected by N&P pollution. Recovery of N&P could not only prevent them from entering waterbodies at point-source discharges, but also provide a supply of these essential resources.

Smarter N&P nutrient removal, recovery and reuse at wastewater treatment facilities has been intensively studied (Liu et al., 2011; Sengupta et al., 2015; Tong and Chen, 2009; Zhang and Chen, 2009), and today wastewater treatment plants (WWTPs) are shifting toward recovering marketable resources rather than just treating wastewater. The transformation of N&P into an eco-friendly, slow-release fertilizer such as struvite has been demonstrated as an effective approach for N&P removal, recovery and reuse (Liu et al., 2011). Chemicals such as

must be added to precipitate struvite. Also, struvite precipitation is only effective at high N&P concentration (as in swine wastewater); it is not applicable to the ordinary secondary effluent treated in WWTPs.

Adsorption is effective for removing N and P due to its simplicity and low cost. Natural and engineered materials such as volcanic tuff (Maranon et al., 2006), limestone (Hussain et al., 2007), zeolite (He et al., 2019; Karadag et al., 2006; Millar et al., 2016) and biochar (Kizito et al., 2015; Liu et al., 2010) are effective adsorbents for

-N.Metal oxides (e.g., hydrated ferric oxide and lanthanum oxide) on porous supports (e.g., activated carbon or graphite (Wan et al., 2017; Xu et al., 2015), zeolites (Guaya et al., 2015; Pham et al., 2019; Xie et al., 2014) or functionalized polymers (Blaney et al., 2007; Yang et al., 2019)) have been shown to be effective P adsorbents. High N&P sorption capacity using various sorbents has been demonstrated in lab-scale experiments, but developing a cost-effective adsorbent from waste materials would be more sustainable in practical applications.

Proper disposal or recycling of sewage sludge and fly ash is a challenging issue worldwide (Chen et al., 2019; Hu et al., 2018; Li et al., 2018). In China alone, WWTPs generate roughly 60 million tons of sewage sludge per year (Hu et al., 2018). Due to a high concentration of suspended inorganics, a Chinese WWTP produces

more sludge than the world average. Its disposal is usually to a landfill or incinerator, but these methods cannot meet future requirements for environmental protection, a circular economy and sustainability. Fly ash is ultrafine solid waste produced mainly from thermal power plants. About 500 million tons per year is produced in China alone. It is one of the most-generated varieties of industrial solid waste. Although considered as an environmental pollutant, fly ash can potentially be used as a N&P adsorbent owing to its porous structure and high surface area (Hermassi et al., 2017, 2020; Y. Liu et al., 2018; Ugurlu and Karaoglu, 2011).

Direct utilization of sludge and fly ash as adsorbents would bring with their disadvantages such as secondary pollution, poor stability and low mechanical strength (Tang et al., 2014; Yu et al., 2010). The tiny particles of sludge and fly ash make them difficult to use in practical applications such as in fixed-bed reactors. However, calcining fly ash and sludge can produce ceramsite. That has been widely used as an N&P adsorbent (Chen et al., 2020; Cheng et al., 2018; Li et al., 2018; Qin et al., 2015; Wu et al., 2015; Zou et al., 2012). Furthermore, calcining can detoxify any organic pollutants and pathogenic bacteria in the fly ash and sludge, improve its mechanical strength, immobilize possible harmful metals and enhance the adsorption capacity of the resulting ceramsite by generating a microporous structure (Cheng et al., 2018).
The intuition, then is that ceramsite made from sludge and fly ash could remove and recover N&P from municipal wastewater. Although
a number of technologies have demonstrated an ability to recover

-N and P, they have not been widely applied due to their high cost. A technology using mass-produced solid waste promises to substantially reduce the cost and be more sustainable than the technologies currently available. In this work, waste sludge and fly ash (the main components are

, Table S1) were collected from a wastewater treatment plant and thermal power plant, calcined to form ceramsite, and the ceramsite was chemically modified to enhance N&P adsorption. The adsorption mechanism was revealed, and the N&P-bearing ceramsite was used as a fertilizer for plant cultivation to close the N and P cycles.

Sewage sludge, fly ash and clay were used to prepare the ceramsite. The undigested, dewatered sewage sludge was collected from the No. 1 WWTP of the city of Wuhan in China's Hubei Province. The fly ash was collected from Qingshan Thermal Power Plant, also in Wuhan. The clay was collected on the campus of Wuhan University. Those materials' chemical compositions are shown in Table S1. All three were dried at

, ground and passed through a 100-mesh sieve. The sludge, fly ash and clay were then thoroughly mixed according to predetermined mass ratios. Deionized water was added to the mixtures to form a paste. The paste was granulated into round particles
in diameter which were then dried at
. The dried granules were sintered in a muffle furnace at
to yield ceramsite for testing. The estimated heat energy for making

For the use of ceramsite as an absorbent in practical applications, ceramsite need to be installed in fix-beds or filters. Thus, the properties of the ceramsite should meet the standards for filtering materials. In order to reduce the number of experiments to a practical level, Taguchi's

method was used to optimize the ceramsite as a filtering material (Yang and Tarng, 1998). Based on the Chinese standard for artificial ceramsite filters in water treatment (Mohurd, 2008), specific surface area (SSA) and the sum of the breakage and the wear rates (SBWR, representing the filter's strength) were selected as the evaluation parameters in optimizing the ceramsite's formula. The synthesis conditions varied in the optimization were the mass ratios of the three components, the preheating temperature, the preheating time, the sintering temperature and the sintering time (Table S2).
The as-prepared ceramsite was modified to enhance its N&P adsorption performance. To prepare ceramsite optimized for N adsorption (designated as ceramsite-N), pristine ceramsite was added into
solution at solid-liquid ratios from 1/3 to

on the ceramsite's surface. The as-obtained ceramsite-P was washed until the leachate had a neutral pH. It is estimated that

is the ceramsite dosage (g). The N and P adsorption kinetics and isotherms were documented. The duration for isotherm tests is 24 h, ensuring a full establishment of adsorption equilibrium for both N and P. Also studied were the effects on the adsorption of ceramsite dosage (over the range 5-70 g/L), the initial N or P concentration (5-100 mg/L), temperature (15-35 Â°C), pH (pH 3-11) and the presence of Na+, K+, CaÂ²âº, MgÂ²âº, Clâ», Fâ», SOâÂ²â», HCOââ», COâÂ²â» and humic acid.
Real WWTP effluent was collected from the secondary sedimentation tank of Zuoling municipal WWTP in Wuhan. Its concentration of
and that of total P was about
. The adsorption experiments were carried out in a benchtop acrylic column
tall with an inner diameter of
min, maintained by a peristaltic pump. The wastewater flowed upward through a ceramsite-N layer

(Fig. S1). The ceramsite-N and ceramsite-P layers were separated by a porous mat in the column. The outflow was sampled for the determination of N and P concentrations at predetermined times. The breakthrough points for N and P were
Subsequently, the N- and P-loaded ceramsite was collected from the column and used to fertilize growing Impatiens commelinoides. Those experiments were carried out in polypropylene flowerpots
deep. Three groups of Impatiens commelinoides were cultivated, each group consisting of three replicates, for a total of 9 pots. The bedding material consisted of

ceramsite-P for group I (pots A, B and C), pristine ceramsite for group II (pots D, E and F), and commercial ceramsite for group III (pots G, H and I). The differences in sprouting, plant height, stem diameter and weight were recorded. In the germination stage, 10 Impatiens commelinoides seeds were sown in each pot with uniform spacing. The cultivation substrate was watered thoroughly once, and then kept moist throughout the experiment. Any germination was recorded at 8:00 a.m. every day, and the seedling's lengths were also measured. After the germination stage (about 15 days), nine uniform Impatiens commelinoides seedlings with similar growth conditions and length (about
) were selected from the group I pots and randomly transplanted in with the pots of group I, II and III. During the growth stage the plants were watered with about
of water every day and no additional nutrients were added. The humidity was controlled at between

of sunlight illumination per day. The plant's heights were measured twice a week, and the stem diameter was measured with a vernier caliper on the same schedule. After the flowering stage the plants were harvested and immediately weighed. They were then dried in an oven at
until a constant dry weight was achieved.
-N was measured spectrophotometrically using Nessler reagent (Zhou and Boyd, 2016). The P concentrations

were determined colorimetrically (Heiberg et al., 2010). The ceramsite particles' specific surface area, SBWR, apparent density, bulk density and solubility in hydrochloric acid were measured. The ceramsite's toxicity was analyzed according to the Chinese standard (GB 5085.3-2007) for the extraction toxicity of hazardous wastes (Protection, 2007). Heavy metal elements in the leachate were analyzed by inductively-coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP). BET surface areas were measured with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 physisorption analyzer. The crystal structure of the ceramsite was determined using a Panaco XPert PRO X-ray diffractometer. The surface morphologies of the ceramsite were measured with a Hitachi S-520 scanning electron microscope (SEM). X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were obtained using a Kratos Axis Ultra DLD instrument.

The sustainability of the technologies proposed in this work was evaluated in the context of Wuhan's Jiangxia WWTP using the analysis technique explained in Text S1 (Zhang et al., 2009). The analysis was in terms of emergy, defined as "the available energy of one kind (usually solar emergy joules) used up directly and indirectly to generate a service or product" (Odum, 1996). Emergy theory was proposed in the late 1980s and has become an evaluation methodology integrating ecological and economic considerations. In the past 30 years, emergy analysis has been successfully applied to various systems on various scales in ecological and economic value accounting (Z. Liu et al., 2018). In this study, landfill, incineration, and this study's ceramic site production and utilization were evaluated in the Jiangxia WWTP's context. Sewage treatment, reclaimed water treatment and dehydrated sludge treatment and disposal were all considered using the emergy yield ratio (EYR), environmental load ratio (ELR) and an emergy sustainable index (ESI). Those metrics consider natural resource utilization along with the waste's environmental impact. Definitions of EYR, ELR and ESI, and detailed description of the methods of the emergy analysis were presented in Text S2 (Odum, 1983).

A flow chart for the ceramsite synthesis is shown in Fig. 1a. The synthesis conditions were optimized using an orthogonal experimental design (Table S2, Text S3). In doing so, 16 types of ceramsite were prepared. Their specific surface areas and SBWRs are presented in Table S3. The optimum conditions for ceramsite synthesis were as follows: a fly ash/sludge/clay mass ratio of
The as-prepared pristine ceramsite particles were reddish-brown and

in diameter (Fig. 1b). The material's physical properties met the requirements of Chinese standard CJ/T299-2008 for artificial ceramsite filter material for water treatment (Table S4). The material's potential toxicity was evaluated by testing for heavy metals in the leachates (Table S5). The heavy metal concentrations were all far below the limits set out in Chinese standard GB 5085.3-2007 (Protection, 2007). Thus, using the ceramsite in wastewater treatment would not cause secondary contamination. Two prominent characteristic peaks at

(Fig. 1c). The mullite gave the ceramsite good mechanic strength, and the cations

Pseudo-first and pseudo-second order kinetic models were fitted (Figs. 3b and S9, Table S10). Pseudo-second order kinetics described the data well, with a calculated adsorption capacity of
. The pseudo-second order kinetics suggest the adsorption is mainly chemical, which is in line with the findings of phosphate sorption onto other lanthanum-based sorbents (Fang et al., 2018).

The initial pH had little influence on ceramsite-Ps adsorption capacity (Fig. 3c). The equilibrium pH was close to 7 regardless of the initial pH, and the initial pH had little effect. The effect of pH on P adsorption by pristine ceramsite was studied to explain this buffering effect. The equilibrium pH was again close to 7, demonstrating that the buffering resulted from the ceramsite itself, not the modification. The main component of ceramsite is

(Fig. S10, Fig. 3g). The shifted binding energy demonstrates the formation of inner-sphere complexes between phosphate and La (Fang et al., 2018). The La's 3d XPS of the ceramsite-P showed two

nanosheets on the ceramsite-P was no longer observed after P adsorption, indicating the possible formation of
on the surface of the ceramsite-P (Fig. S11).
3.4. N&P recovery from real wastewater and its reuse for plant growth
When real WWTP effluent was passed through the mixed ceramsite-N and ceramsite-P column, the ceramsite-N purified 10.44 times the bed's volume (5.22 L) of wastewater before breakthrough at
-N. The ceramsite-P purified 7.56 times the bed's volume (3.78 L) before breakthrough at
When the saturated ceramsite was used for Impatiens commelinoides cultivation the germination percentage was similar to that with virgin ceramsite:
at day 15 (Figs. 5a, S12). The germination percentage for commercial ceramsite was

at day 15. Fig. 5b shows the changes in average seedling length of each group during the germination stage. The seedling lengths with the saturated ceramsite were longer than those of the pristine ceramsite group throughout the period, which indicates that the N and P adsorbed on the ceramsite effectively promoted the growth of Impatiens commelinoides seedlings. By the 15th day the average seedling length for the N&P-adsorbed ceramsite group was
, for the pristine ceramsite group it was
, and for the commercial ceramsite it was only

. Fig. S13 shows that the seedlings cultivated in N&P-adsorbed ceramsite and pristine ceramsite had developed roots, while the roots of the seedlings cultivated in commercial ceramsite were poorly developed. This demonstrates the availability of nutrients in the pristine ceramsite (likely from the sludge used in its synthesis) and on the surface of the used material.
During the growth stage, the average height of the plant in N&P-adsorbed ceramsite group was greater than in the other two groups

and their growth was more rapid (Fig. 5c). The average plant height of the N&P-adsorbed ceramsite group was
for the virgin ceramsite and only

for the commercial ceramsite group. Fig. 5d shows that the average stem diameter in N&P-adsorbed ceramsite group was also larger than the other two groups' averages, especially after the 30th day. The fresh and dry weight of Impatiens commelinoides cultivated in N&P-adsorbed ceramsite averaged

, significantly more than those of the plants cultivated in the other two substrates (Fig. 5e, f). The plants grown in N&P-adsorbed ceramsite grew fast, developing healthy and luxuriant leaves, and the roots were well developed and coupled with strong shoots (Fig. S14). Growth in the other materials was weaker, especially in the late growth stage. In the commercial ceramsite group the growth was slow and the leaves turned yellow and fell off easily the 30th day, due presumably to a lack of nutrients. In addition, the stems could not hold the plants upright and the root system was underdeveloped. In conclusion, N&P-adsorbed ceramsite can provide N and P to
nourish Impatiens commelinoides over its entire growth period (Table S11).

Sustainability is a multi-dimensional concept, in which economic, social and environmental aspects must be equally considered and integrated (Pope et al., 2004). An appropriate tool for a multi-dimensional representation must be a suitable set of indicators developed as an integral part of an assessment methodology to be used for the purposes of measuring sustainability. In the regard of sustainability studies associated with emergy analysis, the emergy accounting approach has been applied to multi-scales for its significant advantages of integrating ecological system and economic system into one common unit (solar emergy) and make the results comparable (Brown and Ulgiati, 1997; Liu et al., 2016; Zhang et al., 2011). In this study, the sustainability of the proposed technologies was evaluated with the Jiangxia WWTP as
Fig. 6. Diagrams of (a) the emergy system analyzed and (b) the proposed N and P cycles.
Q. Shao, Y. Zhang, Z. Liu et al.

the context. The original data needed for emergy analysis were obtained through field investigation. Unit emergy values (UEVs) were obtained from published sources (Text S2). Various measurement unitsâJ, kg or $âwere converted into a unified solar energy value for the emergy analysis (Fig. 6a, Tables S12â15). Three sewage treatment ecosystems, i.e. "Sludge to landfill system", "Sludge incineration system" and "Ceramsite production system", were analyzed, and each treatment ecosystems consist of treatment of sewage, reclaimed water and dewatered sludge (Fig. S15). The input of the sewage and reclaimed water treatment subsystem was taken as including the sewage waste stream
, purchased renewable resource emergy valued at
, and purchased nonrenewable resource emergy worth
. The output of the system was treated water
generated from the reuse of the reclaimed water, the energy value of the waste discharged from reclaimed water
imposed on the environment. The input of the sludge landfilling subsystem includes the dewatered sludge
. The output of the system was the energy value of the waste discharged from the dewatered sludge landfill

imposed on the environment. The detailed description of the emergy analysis for the incineration system and the ceramsite system were presented in Text S6 and Tables S12â15. The emergy flow and emergy index for the three ecosystems were estimated (Table 1). The renewable resource
solar emjoules per year, sej/a) purchased by the incineration system was the largest, followed by the ceramsite system (
sej/a) (Table 1). The incineration system consumes more electricity than the landfill system or the ceramsite system. In terms of the purchased non-renewable resources

is the highest because sodium hydroxide and lanthanum chloride were used for the modification of ceramsite-N and ceramsite-P, respectively. Also, sodium hydroxide is also used for the treatment of flue gas during the ceramsite firing process. Thus, these agents account for a large proportion of the purchased non-renewable resources. Therefore, from the perspective of total input, the ceramsite system's (
sej/a) is slightly greater than that of the incineration system (

represents dewatered sludge treatment subsystem. ELR abbreviates a system's environment load ratio. ESI abbreviates emergy sustainability index, and detailed description of the methods of the emergy analysis are shown in Text S2.

landfill system (1.1602E+21 sej/a). In terms of the monetary value of the products, the ceramsite system's (5.1625E+19 sej/a) is much greater than those of the others (the incineration and landfill systems are both 3.6997E+19 sej/a). The N and P nutrients adsorbed on the ceramsite bring lots of economic value. As for the waste stream

discharged from the system to the environment, the landfill system is the highest (1.1513E+21 sej/a), followed by incineration (1.1492E+21 sej/a), and the ceramsite system (1.1492E+21 sej/a). The pressure on the environment brought by the sludge is much greater if it goes to a landfill compared with incineration and using it to produce ceramsite.

The ceramsite system has the highest EYR value of 1.30. Incineration's is 1.04 and the landfill system's is 1.01 (Table 1). The ELR of the ceramsite system (11.07) is slightly larger than that of the landfill system (11.03) and the incineration system (10.35). Although
is the smallest with ceramsite, the cost of the chemicals to modify it is relatively high, resulting in the largest
. However, as the EYR of the ceramsite system is very high, the order of sustainability indices is the ceramsite system (0.12) > incineration (0.10) > landfilling (0.09).

The ceramsite system was further compared with other adsorbents derived from solid waste in terms of cost and economic value (Text S7 and Tables S16-19). It is found that the preparation cost of ceramsite-N is lower than other adsorbents, and that of ceramsite-P is just higher than furnace slag. In terms of produced economic value, ceramsite-N is lower than Na@La-modified zeolite, but higher than biochar and iron-loaded activated carbon. Ceramsite-P has a lower P adsorption capacity and produces economic value lower than other P adsorbents. However, our work has unitized both ceramsite-N and ceramsite-P for plant cultivation, which replace fertilized soil. Thus, the economic value of ceramsite is greater than other adsorbents. Other adsorbents may have a larger adsorption capacity, but they are usually in a powder form and are difficult to be used in practical applications.

All in all, we report a proof of concept to close the N and P cycle using ceramsite made from solid waste (Fig. 6b). N and P are nutrients are essential for all living organisms but cause eutrophication problems in waters when in excess. In industry, ammonia-nitrogen is produced through the energy-intensive Haber-Bosch process, and phosphate fertilizer is produced from non-renewable phosphorus-containing rock. That makes the recovery and reuse of
-N and P very desirable for minimizing the eutrophication problems and closing the N and P cycles for sustainability. Several sophisticated technologies have demonstrated the feasibility of

-N and P recovery, but they have not yet been widely applied due to their high cost compared with producing N and P fertilizers industrially. Technologies using mass-produced solid waste can potentially reduce the cost substantially and be more sustainable than other technologies. This work used sewage sludge and fly ash to fabricate ceramsite, which after modification can effectively remove and recover N and P nutrients from wastewater treatment plant effluent. Importantly, the ceramsite with the recovered N and P nutrients can be used as an eco-friendly, slow-release fertilizer to promote plant growth. Our study demonstrates a sustainable solution combining the recovery and reuse of solid waste and the extraction of N and P nutrients from wastewater, closing the N and P cycle and minimizing the environmental impact of wastewater effluent and solid waste disposal.

This study has demonstrated producing ceramsite from sewage sludge and fly ash. Its physical properties and safety met the relevant Chinese standards for wastewater treatment filters. Ceramsite-N was shown to effectively recover

-N from real municipal wastewater via ion exchange. Ceramsite-P was shown to be effective for recovering phosphate. Saturated ceramsite used as fertilizer promotes the germination, growth and blooming of Impatiens commelinoides, realizing the recycling of N and P from wastewater. Emergy analysis shows that
Q. Shao, Y. Zhang, Z. Liu et al.

applying this technology in a real WWTP is more sustainable than the current approaches for sludge disposal. In summary, N and P can be removed from wastewater, recovered and reused as fertilizer with the aid of ceramsite made from solid waste. This provides a profitable and sustainable solution for closing the N and P cycle.
